title: 5,700 Mature Trees Won’t Be Cut, Instead Transplanted Elsewhere To Build Dwarka Expressway
text:
5,700 Mature Trees Won’t Be Cut, Instead Transplanted Elsewhere To Build Dwarka Expressway

5,700 Mature Trees Won’t Be Cut, Instead Transplanted Elsewhere To Build Dwarka Expressway

In what could pave way for better management of trees for development purposes, 5,700 fully grown trees will be transplanted elsewhere to build the Dwarka Expressway, providing another link to Gurgaon.

This perhaps is the biggest transplantation drive in the country.

The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has close to three to four months to finish the job and while officials say they are on the job, they insist that an extension in time is required in order to save maximum trees.

Experts said the process took one to one-and-a-half years and there was no need to take care of the transplanted trees any further.

Representational Image

According to a report by The Times of India, NHAI officials deployed at the site said they are taking all necessary measures to carefully transplant the trees, understanding growing public concern around protecting nature.

“This is a Herculean task. The idea is not just to transplant but also to ensure that the trees survive. The project developer has been directed to ensure that the transplanted trees get best care,” an NHAI official at the site told TOI.

Ajay Nagar, who had carried out successful transplantation for Lucknow Metro and for a road project in Sitarganj (Uttarakhand) in the past three years, has been engaged for this task.

He said transplanted trees need utmost care till the time they are fully back to life.

Representational Image

If the process is followed correctly, there’s a 80-85 per cent chance of survival, he added.

The trees were being transplanted in sector parks and roads of Dwarka.

The entire project of transplantation will cost the NHAI close to Rs 70 crore. For transplanting one tree, the government agency is spending around Rs 30,000.

Public interest in protecting trees has grown manifold as awareness around climate change and global warming spreads. The overnight felling of trees in Mumbai’s Aarey Colony to build a metro shed sparked massive public outrage, following which the Supreme Court had to intervene and order stay on cutting of trees.
